translated: Commentary on the Treatise on the Mind of Dependent Origination in one fascicle
In explaining this treatise, first, it is analyzed in four aspects. Then, the text of the main treatise is explained.
The four aspects are: first, clarifying the author of the treatise; second, clarifying the
cause of composing the treatise;
third, clarifying whether the treatise that is expounded is correct or not;
fourth, distinguishing the tenets of the treatise.
First, clarifying the author of the treatise:
It was composed by the great master NÄgÄrjuna, who perfected his own benefit and that of others and realized the ground of extreme joy.
He skillfully saw the profound nature of dependent origination.
He was prophesied by the Well-Gone One and his fame was widely known.
It was composed by one who possesses all virtues.
Second, clarifying the cause of composing the treatise:

It was in order to eliminate the nets of doubts of the five virtuous disciples, to destroy the heterodox views of eternalism and annihilationism, and to eliminate various biased attachments. It was in order to enable future beings of dull faculties and those of sharp faculties to skillfully understand dependent origination and clearly understand the two truths.
The correct cause for quickly attaining unsurpassed enlightenment, therefore this treatise is composed. Those who wish to cultivate the correct cause for unsurpassed enlightenment,
First, they must skillfully understand the principle of the two truths, which clearly distinguishes the principles of dependent origination, dependent nature, defilement, and purity.
As for the two truths,
They are the two truths of ultimate truth and conventional truth. As for ultimate truth,
The nature and characteristics of all dharmas are unborn, unarisen, not annihilated, and not eternal.
Beyond the realm of words and thoughts,
It is the realm of self-realization by the sages alone. As for conventional truth,
To speak briefly, there are four kinds.
First, the real;
Second, the unreal;
Third, the proximate ultimate;
Fourth, the pure. As for the real,
It refers to the internal and external dependent origination. In the ultimate truth,
Although empty and devoid of substance, in the conventional truth gate, it is still like illusory transformations, accomplished by the power of causes and conditions.ğŸ”½The sages see its faults,
While the foolish grasp at reality and do not see its problems.
Dwelling in birth and death for a long time. As for not true,
It refers to things like mirages, illusions, and castles in the sky.
In the conventional truth, they are not able to accomplish anything.
Even ordinary people can understand this without relying on the teachings of sages. As for close to ultimate truth,
In order to explain ultimate truth,
The buddhas, bodhisattvas, and good and wise advisors
Use names, phrases, and sentences to establish the twelve divisions of the teachings.
Although those names, phrases, and sentences are not the actual events,
If there were no names, etc., they would not be able to manifest events. Therefore, names, phrases, etc. are called close to ultimate truth. As for pure,

It refers to the various marks, excellent features, powers, fearlessnesses, and other vast merits possessed by the buddhas and tathÄgatas, which are unlike the defiled and afflicted karmas of ordinary beings.
They are only produced by the pure supramundane dharmas. Therefore, it is said to be pure.
Third, it is asked whether the treatise that is composed is a correct measure or not.
There is a question here.
The dependent origination and dependent nature taught by the TathÄgata are very profound and subtle.
Although they can be understood, only the Buddha has realized them.
At what stage of attainment is NÄgÃ¢rjuna the Great Master?
On what basis can this treatise he composed be trusted and accepted?
The answer is: because there are proofs in both the teachings and principles.
This treatise that he composed is without error.
It is taken as the correct standard.ğŸ”½Do not give rise to doubt.
As for the proof by the standard of the teachings,
the Laá¹…kÄvatÄra SÅ«tra says:
In the country of southern India, there is a bhiká¹£u with a famous virtue.
His name is NÄgÃ¢rjuna.
He is able to destroy the doctrines of existence and non-existence.
In the world, he reveals my unsurpassed MahÄyÄna Dharma.ğŸ”½He attains the first ground of joy and is reborn in the Land of Bliss.
The MahÃ¢calasÃ»tra also says:

There is this teaching and standard, and he is prophesied.
Therefore, this master's compositions are considered reliable. As for the rational proofs,
this master, while alive, attained the samÄdhi of the emptiness treasury.
Waving his hand, treasures emerged to fulfill the wishes of sentient beings.
He was unimpeded by mountains, rocks, and walls.
There are even more excellent qualities, but they are not described here due to length.
As explained elsewhere.
Using this direct perception, it is inferred that this master is not ordinary.
The teachings spoken by the sages are taken as the correct teachings.
They are worthy of being transmitted.
Fourth, the main tenets of the debate.
While the great master was alive, the teachings of the HÄ«nayÄna and MahÄyÄna were each without difference.
They were mutually like what the Buddha taught, and practitioners relied on the teachings to cultivate.
After the Buddha's nirvÄá¹‡a, the teachings of the HÄ«nayÄna and MahÄyÄna were differently grasped by various masters.
Each formed many tenets, as explained elsewhere.
Now, this treatise.
The tenet that is expounded is not HÄ«nayÄna but MahÄyÄna.
Within the MahÄyÄna, it is further divided into three tenets.
First, the ultimate is all empty.
Second, the principle is perfect and real.
Third, the perfect interfusion of the three natures.
The Bodhisattva Nagarjuna, the one to whom this treatise is addressed, relied on the Mahaprajnaparamita Sutra and other scriptures to establish his standpoint.
Therefore, this treatise is included in the school of the emptiness of ultimate reality.
As for the latter statement explaining the actual text,
the text is divided into two parts.
First, explaining the title of the treatise.
Second, clarifying the actual treatise.
In the explanation of the title, it says The Treatise on the Mind of Dependent Origination in Verse.
The names established by various sutras and treatises all have four meanings.
First, person.
Second, place.
Third, metaphor.
Fourth, meaning.
The name here is established based on meaning.
Because in this treatise,
all the meanings of dependent origination, whether extensive or concise, worldly or supramundane, defiled or extinguished,
are completely included here, so this name is established. As for dependent origination,
this refutes the theories of annihilation, permanence, and causelessness, and various wrong views. As for dependent origination,
what does it refer to?
The Yoga and Abhidharma Collection say:
The meaning of being apart from activity.
The meaning of being produced from causes.
The meaning of being apart from sentient beings.
The meaning of being dependent on others.ğŸ”½The meaning of being without movement or change.
The meaning of impermanence.
The meaning of temporarily abiding.
The meaning of the uninterrupted continuity of causes and effects.
The meaning of the similarity of causes and effects.
The meaning of the various causes and effects.
The meaning of the individual determination of causes and effects.
This is the meaning of dependent arising. As for the word mind,
dependent arising and dependent nature are the secret treasury of the minds of all buddhas, the realm of reality.
Because this treatise also clarifies this meaning,
it is therefore called mind. The word mind
is also a comprehensive term.
Because it comprehensively includes all extensive meanings. As for the word treatise,
it is called a treatise because it admonishes students.
The two words clarify the correct treatise
are divided into two main sections.
First, extensive.
Second, brief.
As for the extensive,
The first five verses in the seven-verse section are like this. Brief refers to the last two verses.
Within the extensive [explanation], it is further divided into five parts.
The first is the three-fold inclusion of the twelve factors, which is the first two verses.
The second is the door of mutual arising of the twelve factors without beginning or end, which is the third verse.
The third is the door of the emptiness of the twelve factors, which is half a verse in the verse.
The fourth is the door of the twelve factors being free from the two extremes and thus without transition,
which is from Only arising from empty dharmas to without transition in the verse.
The fifth is the door of cessation and return, which is the verse Wisdom should observe.
Among those five, the first four are in the forward order,
while the last one is in the reverse order.
One should contemplate in accordance with reason.
Within the two doors of extensive and concise, the extensive one is explained first.
Within the extensive [explanation], the first is now the door of the three-fold inclusion of the twelve factors.
The text has two parts.
First, a question is asked.
Second, an answer is given.
As for the question, it is the first half of the verse.
As for the later answer, the last one and a half verses are matched with the text. First, the question is briefly explained.
Here means
the words that give rise to the teaching, namely the two teachings of the TathÄgata's extensive and concise teachings on dependent origination and the nature of conditions. As for Å›ramaá¹‡a,
this is an Indian word.
It means well-learned.
It also means peaceful and tranquil.
This refers to the sages and the renunciant assembly that follows the sages.
This is common to both internal and external studies. As for those who delight in hearing,
this is to block disbelief and lack of delight.
Although there are many kinds of desire, here it means desiring to clearly hear the meaning of dependent origination. As for those who are able to listen,
this means the ear faculty is unimpaired and clearly understands sounds. As for those who are able to skillfully remember,
this means the meaning heard by the ear faculty before
is remembered by the mental consciousness and focused on a single object without forgetting. As for those who are able to understand,
this means the meaning understood by the mental consciousnessğŸ”½.
Using wisdom, one skillfully contemplates the meaning of the sounds one hears.
Without rejecting anything, one thoroughly understands it. As for being able to contemplate,
one skillfully observes the merits and faults of the Dharma and the path of liberation.
As for being equipped with discernment and abandonment,
one skillfully discerns the merits and faults of the defiled and pure aspects, as well as doubts and evil thoughts.
The first five virtues are the wisdom of hearing,
one is the wisdom of reflection,
and the last two are the wisdom of cultivation.
Although it is said to be five virtues, it is also equipped with the five good thoughts.
One should contemplate according to the principle of abandoning the five evil thoughts. As for coming to the teacher's place,
it means that the disciple with five virtues comes to NÄgÃ¢rjuna Bodhisattva in order to seek the Dharma. As for in the teachings of the TathÃ¢gata,
the disciple with five virtues does not have doubts in the teachings of the six non-Buddhist teachers,
but only gives rise to doubts in the two meanings of dependent origination, extensive and concise, taught by the TathÃ¢gata, and thus asks questions. As for BhagavÄn,
this means subduing.
Complete means possessing the four demon-subduing and six merits. Question:
As for the term bhagavat,
is it only the TathÄgata who can be called this?
Why do we call the teacher bhagavat? Answer:
It is because the disciples regard the teacher as the TathÄgata,

and it is a respectful term. Moreover, this NÄgÄrjuna, abiding in the stage of the path of seeing, abandons all evil dharmas and is far removed from the realm of MÄra. The sÅ«tra has a sincere statement:
All dharmas are like illusions.
For the sake of sentient beings,
he has no fear.
Therefore, he is called bhagavat.
Bodhisattva NÄgÄrjuna realized the ground of extreme joy and understood dependent origination to be like illusions and transformations, etc.
Since he possesses these virtues, it is not contrary to reason. As for the disciples calling the teacher bhagavat,
what do they seek?
It is for the sake of extinguishing craving,
for the sake of liberation,
not for the sake of wealth or the fruits of love. As for the statement where is he included?
It is because those disciples may have already understood the extensive meaning.
But they are not skilled in summarizing.
Therefore, they ask about the summarized meaning. As for saying now wish to happily hear,
although they say they wish to happily hear, it also includes contemplation and cultivation to attain the fruit. Later, it clarifies the answer, saying:
Knowing that they ask about the true meaning,

means that NÄgÄrjuna Bodhisattva knows that those five virtuous disciples, regarding the dependent origination, the nature of dependent origination, the nature of all that exists, and the nature of things as they are,
in the true meaning, give rise to thirst and longing without being contrary to the Dharma.
Therefore, he tests them by asking. As for saying the teacher then called out to him, saying 'you',
it means that disciple previously gave rise to the thought of the TathÄgata towards the teacher.
Calling him bhagavat is in accord with him. As for teacher,
among the five kinds of teachers, it is the one who gives the going forth ordination, the one who gives the precepts, and the one who gives the instructions. As for you,
it is the disciple.
There are three kinds of disciples.
The first is born from the body.
The second is born from the mouth.
The third is born from the mind.
Now, the latter two are taken. As for making this clear,
And the words are not contradictory to the meaning, answering the questions as they are asked.
Therefore it is said to be clear. As for the words of the treatise,
The words are without error and without confusion.
The meaning is clear and benefits the audience, with results to be gained.
The following is a further explanation of the question and answer in the commentary. As for saying here it is ten and two, thus called twelve,
If ten and two are not spoken of separately, the number becomes twenty.
There is the error of addition, thus this is said. As for the question,
It does not say eleven.
It does not say thirteen.
It definitely says twelve.
What does it mean?
If it says eleven, the meaning is not complete.
If it says thirteen, the meaning is useless.
There is the error of addition and subtraction, thus it is definitely twelve. Moreover, it uses twelve for the causes and effects of the three periods of time.
That is to say, from the past to the present, the causes are ignorance, karmic formations, and consciousness.
The effects are name-and-form.
The assisting causes are craving.
From the middle period up to the causes in the latter period, from consciousness up to feeling.
The effect refers to birth, old age, and death.
The contributory cause is grasping and becoming.
The one abiding in the middle period is from consciousness up to feeling.
Therefore, there are definitely twelve. Moreover, the twelve are as follows:
The first three are the leading factors.
Name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, and feeling are the led factors.
Craving, grasping, and becoming are the completing factors.
The one factor of birth is the completed factor.
Old age and death are the detrimental factors.ğŸ”½The leading factors
manifest its distant causes.ğŸ”½The completing factors
immediately show the proximate causes.
If these two did not exist, birth would not be accomplished. As for saying that the factors are distinctions, it is said that they are called factors because they are like the parts of a chariot.
Apart from the twelve factors, there are no other distinctions.
It is because the natures, characteristics, and functions of the twelve factors themselves are different that distinctions are established. The meaning is like the parts of a chariot.
If one separates from the wheels, etc., there is no chariot.
It is also like this.
As for the characteristics of the twelve factors of dependent origination,
it is as explained in the Rice Sheaf Treatise.

What is ignorance? It is giving rise to the notion of oneness, the notion of unity, the notion of permanence, the notion of solidity, the notion of indestructibility, the notion of bliss, the notion of sentient beings, the notion of a living being, the notion of a person, the notion of a human, the notion of a pudgala, the notion of a youth, the notion of an agent, the notion of I and mine, and so forth.
And other kinds of ignorance.
This is ignorance.
Because there is ignorance, one gives rise to craving, anger, and delusion towards sense objects.
As for giving rise to craving, anger, and delusion towards sense objects,
this is ignorance as a condition for volitional formations.
As for being able to cognize things,
this is called consciousness.
The four appropriated aggregates that arise together with consciousness,
this is called name-and-form.
The faculties based on name-and-form,
are called the six sense bases.
The union of the three factors is called contact.
Experiencing contact through awareness,
is called feeling.
Craving after feeling,
is called craving.
Increasing craving.
The growth of craving is called grasping.
From grasping, there is birth.
The karma that is produced is called existence.
The aggregates that are produced from those causes are called birth.
After birth, the maturation of the aggregates is called aging.
After aging, the destruction of the aggregates is called death.
At the time of death, the internal possession of craving and distress is called sorrow.
The various words that arise from sorrow are called lamentation.
The suffering experienced by the five sense consciousnesses is called suffering.
The suffering experienced by the mind consciousness is called distress.ğŸ”½The possession of these and the secondary afflictions is called affliction.
As for the functions of the twelve factors of dependent origination,
it is as explained in the Abhidharma-samuccaya:
What function does ignorance perform?
It causes sentient beings to be confused about existence.
It also serves as a condition for the various activities.
What function do the activities perform that they manifest sentient beings in the various destinies?
They also serve as the condition for the arising of habitual tendencies for consciousness.
What function does consciousness perform that it holds the bonds of sentient beings' karma?
It also serves as a condition for name-and-form.
What function does name-and-form perform that it causes sentient beings to take on a body?
It also serves as a condition for the six sense bases.

What function do the six sense bases perform that they cause sentient beings to fully perfect the experience of the body? Contact serves as a condition.ğŸ”½What function does contact perform that it causes sentient beings to experience objects? Sensation serves as a condition.
What function does sensation perform that it causes sentient beings to experience rebirth? Craving serves as a condition.
What function does craving perform that it causes sentient beings to lead to rebirth? Grasping serves as a condition.
What function does grasping perform? Because it grasps subsequent existence, it causes sentient beings to have grasping consciousness and existence.
What karma causes sentient beings to move towards and enter into future existences?
What karma causes sentient beings to gradually accomplish name-and-form and the six sense bases,
and to be the conditions for contact, feeling, and old age and death?
What karma causes sentient beings to repeatedly transform their lifespan and life force? The explanation of the names of the twelve links of dependent arising is as follows.
As explained in the Rice Sheaf Treatise.
Because it is a great darkness, it is called ignorance.
Because it creates, it is called formations.
Because it cognizes, it is called consciousness.
Because they rely on each other, it is called name-and-form.
Because it serves as the gateway for birth, it is called the six sense bases.
Because of contact, it is called contact.
Because of feeling, it is called feeling.
Because of thirst, it is called craving.
Because of grasping, it is called grasping.ğŸ”½Because it gives rise to future existences, it is called becoming.
Because it gives rise to the aggregates, it is called birth.
Because the aggregates mature, it is called old age.
Because the aggregates decay, it is called death.
Because of sorrow, it is called sorrow.
Because of lamentation, it is called lamentation.ğŸ”½Because it afflicts the body, it is called suffering.
Because it afflicts the mind, it is called distress.
Because of afflictions, it is called distressed. As for saying it is able to pacify body and speech, it is called benevolent,
Although it does not say that it is able to pacify body and speech from the mind, it arises from the pure cause of the mind.
But it only knows the pure effect.
Therefore, it does not say that the cause is pure.
As for saying that it is not the intrinsic nature,
There are ten kinds below this.
This is the first of the heterodox attachments of non-Buddhists.
Namely, the naked non-Buddhist sect holds the six dharmas to be the intrinsic nature of dharmas.
First, having life.
Second, having no life.
Third, having outflows.
Fourth, obtaining bondage.
Fifth, upholding precepts.
Sixth, liberation.
If one does not discern these six dharmas, one will revolve in birth and death.
If one discerns them, one will attain liberation.
There is a type that holds the subtle dust of sentient beings to be the intrinsic nature of equality.
That very person is the intrinsic nature of dharmas.
Second, as for the two statements,
This is the school of the SÄá¹ƒkhya non-Buddhist sect.

That is the cause.
Therefore, cause and effect are each determined, and the destinies of humans, gods, etc.,
are not mixed up and abide in the wheel of birth and death.
Third, as for the person,
this is also the school of SÄá¹ƒkhya.
It refers to a certain type who holds that there is
a sentient being and a person as the cause of all dharmas.
Not understanding these two, one abides in birth and death for a long time.
Although they are mixed up, if one distinguishes them, one attains liberation.
As for the person,
there are a thousand verses well-explained by the Dharma master.
Or it is held that the person has great power,
each abiding in the body of sentient beings.
Fourth, as for the mutual dependence,
it refers to a certain type of non-Buddhist who says:
The days, months, stars, and days are the cause of the Dharma.
In accordance with the practice, one accomplishes the matter.
If one goes against it, then it will not be accomplished.
Therefore, all dharmas are their own nature.
If one does not understand them, one will remain in the cycle of rebirth for a long time.
If one does understand them, one will attain liberation.
As for the term dependent on each other,
there are non-Buddhists who give rise to such views
and establish such doctrines.
They say that if there are sentient beings
who bathe their limbs in the Ganges River and other [rivers],
they will attain purity by bathing their limbs.
There are some who hold that only [certain practices] are considered pure,
not good or evil, which result in different karmic retributions.
But only the methods of bathing in the light of the sun and moon are considered pure.
As for the term self-mastery,
this is also the school of SÄá¹ƒkhya.
It refers to a certain group that says:
The suffering and happiness experienced by sentient beings do not come from good or evil.
Although [the SÄá¹ƒkhyas] claim that [the self] is self-mastery, it is transformed by the present perception of cause and effect.
Because sentient beings in the world do not change according to their desires, they make this assumption.
Why is it so?
It is because sentient beings in the world are seen
If one wishes to cultivate pure karma but does not achieve one's original intention,
one will instead commit evil.
At the time of the fruition,
one wishes to be reborn in a good realm or a world of happiness but does not achieve one's original intention and falls into evil realms and so forth.
In the end, one experiences suffering that does not accord with one's desires.
Because of this view, they think like this.
Sixth, as for time,
this is also the school of SÄá¹ƒkhya.
It means that it is believed that the suffering and happiness experienced by sentient beings do not depend on good or evil,

Seventh, as for spontaneity,

First, substance.

Third, action.
Fourth, totality.

Poor and lacking.

Again, they see someone who, throughout their lifetime, always practices good conduct.
Or practices evil conduct.
They see that upon the end of their life,
they fall into an evil realm.

In the world, they think like this.

The ripening of the fruits of karma.

Sometimes a great wind suddenly arises without reason, and in an instant it completely stops.

Because of this, these three kinds of views arise. And so on means
it includes all the other deviant attachments of non-Buddhists, not just the previous ones.
The tenth says what is produced.
It corresponds one by one with the previous nine texts.
It says this is produced by causes and conditions.
The internal and external dharmas of dependent origination and dependent nature spoken by the Able One have only correct causes and assisting causes.
There is no separate self-nature, determination, and so on.

The second explanation of the treatise below the next initial gate is This distinction of the twelve factors of dependent origination mutually rely on each other like bundles of reeds in the three of afflictions, karma, and suffering. They are all completely included in those three.
It is like the world using bundles of reeds and so forth to establish a house, but a single one cannot be established.

In the same way, the twelve factors of dependent origination are completely included in the three dharmas, which are mutually dependent and jointly create the defiled and pure aspects, causes and effects, without any single dominant one.
If one is missing, it cannot be established. The word completely means the meaning of without remainder.
Among the three dharmas, there is not a single factor of the twelve links that is not completely included, therefore the defiled causes and effects are completely included.
Therefore, the doubts of the five virtuous disciples are all eliminated.
Moreover, the following words it is asked are the text that initiates the answer below. The words it is asked
are the words of the five virtuous disciples asking the teacher. The words what is affliction?
What is karma?
What is seeing suffering?
To which of these differentiated dharmas should they be included? The teacher said:
What are the three dharmas that include the twelve?
You have already explained the words of the canon master clearly, and I have already understood the discrimination.
Among the twelve factors, how many are the path of afflictions, how many are the path of karma, how many are subsumed in the path of suffering, how many are causes, and how many are effects?
I now have doubts and request an explanation, therefore I ask.
As for the phrase answering thus,
it means that the teacher wishes to eliminate the disciple's doubts and responds to them.
As for the phrase the first, eighth, and ninth are afflictions,
it is because these three dharmas disturb sentient beings, the meaning is the same,
therefore they are subsumed in afflictions, but their essences are not the same.
Namely, when ignorance is unclear about an event, it disturbs the mind.ğŸ”½When one is attached to an event, it disturbs the mind.
When one indulges in an event and engages in it, it disturbs the mind.
The DaÅ›abhÅ«mika SÅ«tra says:
The three paths accomplish the truth of suffering and the truth of accumulation. Ignorance, craving, and grasping form a separate defiled path that is uninterrupted.
There are two kinds of action and existence.
The seven other branches of the path of karma are uninterrupted.
This treatise and the sÅ«tra have the same meaning. As for the phrase the second and the tenth are the path of karma,
Because although the characteristics of these two dharmas are different, their meaning of creation is the same, so they are established as the name of karma.

It means that action is created from the door of body, speech, and mind, creating meritorious etc. karma, increasing future existence, and creating karma. As for the statement that the remaining seven are all suffering,
It is because these seven dharmas are all born from the defiled karma of affliction, and have the same characteristic of fruit.
The third is established as the name of suffering because of the nature of the eight sufferings. The sÅ«tras and treatises first list ignorance and finally old age and death.
What is the meaning and sequence of this?
It is because sentient beings from beginningless time have not understood cause and effect and the true nature, and thus have been deluded.
From delusion, there is creation.
The habitual tendencies of action cause the mind to be inverted.
Because the mind is inverted, it continues to be born in the future.
Name and form continue, so the six sense bases are accomplished.
Because the faculties are accomplished, one touches the object.
One then touches and experiences the object.
Because one experiences the object, one is attached to it in the present and gives rise to craving in the future.
Because of birth, there is grasping, seeking, and accumulation.
Because of accumulation, the causes and conditions for future results are established.
Because of establishment, one takes rebirth in the five destinies.
Because of rebirth, there is old age and death.
Sentient beings, from beginningless time, have been revolving in birth and death.
The sequence of causes and effects is like this.
The sequence is like this.
The dharmas such as ignorance each have their own distinctions.
Each dharma has distinctions.
Namely, ignorance has nineteen kinds.ğŸ”½First, ignorance of the past.
Second, ignorance of the future.
Third, ignorance of both.
Fourth, ignorance of the internal.
